sections.procedure:
1.  The case originated in an application (no. 11236/09) against the Republic of Turkey lodged with the Court under Article 34 of the Convention for the Protection of Human Rights and Fundamental Freedoms (“the Convention”) by a Turkish national, Mr Mehmet Aytunç Altay (“the applicant”), on 17 February 2006.
2.  The applicant was represented by Ms G. Tuncer, a lawyer practising in Istanbul. The Turkish Government (“the Government”) were represented by their Agent.
3.  The applicant alleged, in particular, that the restriction of the privacy of his consultations with his lawyer was incompatible with his rights under Article 8 of the Convention and that the domestic proceedings with respect to this measure had not complied with the requirements of Article 6 § 1 of the Convention.
4.  On 17 October 2017 notice of the above complaints was given to the Government and the remainder of the application was declared inadmissible pursuant to Rule 54 § 3 of the Rules of Court.
sections.circumstances:
5.  The applicant was born in 1956 and was convicted of attempting to undermine the constitutional order and sentenced to life imprisonment without the possibility of parole. At the time of the events relating to the application, he was serving his sentence in the Edirne F-type prison.
6.  Since his imprisonment the applicant has been represented by his lawyer in respect of several applications, including the present application, before the Court.
7.  On an unspecified date, the applicant’s lawyer sent a package by post to the applicant. The prison administration believed the contents of the package to be suspect and therefore lodged a request on 12 August 2005 with the public prosecutor for a decision to be taken by an enforcement court to determine whether the material sent to the applicant concerned defence-related documents or whether they concerned any objectionable content so as to prevent them from being handed over to the applicant.
8.  On 25 August 2005 the Edirne Enforcement Court allowed an application by the prosecutor and examined the contents of the package, which contained a book entitled Globalisation and Imperialism ( Küreselleşme ve Emperyalizm) , a magazine with the title Rootless Anational Publication ( Köxüz Anasyonal Neşriyat ), and a newspaper with the title Express International Sha la la ( Express Enternasyonal Şalala ). The court held that the material in question did not relate to the rights of the defence and that therefore they should not be handed over to the applicant pursuant to section 5 of Law no. 5351.
9.  On 16 September 2005 the applicant objected to the decision of the Edirne Enforcement Court before the Edirne Assize Court. He submitted that he had asked his lawyer to bring those books and magazines in question simply because he had wanted to read them. He submitted that it had been the prison administration which had told his lawyer that they could not be brought in person and had therefore to be sent by post. He further argued that while it was correct that they had not been related to his rights of defence, they were not illegal publications and there had been no basis for the prison administration to withhold them from him simply because they had been sent by post by his lawyer.
10.  On 30 September 2005, the Edirne Assize Court dismissed the applicant’s objections on the basis of the case file, holding that the decision of the Edirne Enforcement Court had been in accordance with law and procedure.
11.  In the meantime, that is to say on 16 September 2005, the prison administration lodged another request with the public prosecutor in relation to the package sent by the applicant’s lawyer. In that request, it submitted that the applicant’s lawyer’s conduct had been incompatible with her duties as a lawyer and requested that section 5 of Law no. 5351, which provides for an official to be present during consultations between a prisoner and his or her lawyer, be applied to the applicant.
12.  On 23 September 2005, referring to its earlier decision of 25 August 2005, the Edirne Enforcement Court in an examination carried out on the basis of the case file, without holding a hearing and without seeking submissions from the applicant or his lawyer, granted an application on the part of the prison administration and therefore held that an official was to be present during the applicant’s consultations with his lawyer. The decision did not specify how long the restriction was to remain in force. The Edirne Enforcement Court further held that, if requested, a separate decision would be taken as to whether the exchange of documents between the applicant and his lawyer would also be subject to a restriction.
13.  On 24 October 2005 the applicant objected to the decision of 23 September 2005 before the Edirne Assize Court. He submitted that the impugned decision did not explain why it was necessary to restrict the privacy of his consultations with his lawyer. He argued in that connection that a provision which provided for such a restriction could only be applied if it had emerged from documents and other evidence that visits by lawyers to a person convicted of organised crime had been serving as a means of communication within the criminal organisation in question. He argued that no such element had been present in his situation and the court had not conducted any examination in that connection. Lastly, he maintained that there were no legal provisions prohibiting the exchange of legal books and magazines between a prisoner and his lawyer. The applicant did not request that the examination of his case be carried out by holding a hearing.
14.  On 27 October 2005 the Edirne Assize Court dismissed the case on the basis of the case file and without holding a hearing. Without responding to the applicant’s arguments, it held that the Edirne Enforcement Court’s decision of 23 September 2005 had been in accordance with the law and procedure.
A.  Developments after the introduction of the case
15.  On 29 May 2008 the applicant lodged an application with the Edirne Enforcement Court for the restriction on the conversations between him and his lawyer to be lifted.
16.  On 4 June 2008 the applicant’s application was dismissed on the basis of the case file. The court held that the decision of 23 September 2005 had become final and that there was no need for a further examination.
17.  The applicant lodged another application on 2 November 2010 and applied for a hearing in accordance with the new amendments to the procedure before the enforcement courts (see paragraph 27 below). On 6 December 2010 the Edirne Enforcement Court dismissed the applicant’s application for a hearing, holding that the new amendments to the procedure concerned only the examination of objections against disciplinary sanctions, so that in so far as the restriction of 23 September 2005 had not been a disciplinary sanction, no hearing could be held in respect of that complaint. It further dismissed the applicant’s application for the restriction to be lifted, holding that the decision of 23 September 2005 had been final. An appeal against that decision by the applicant was dismissed on 24 August 2011.
18.  On 21 February 2013 the applicant lodged an application again with the Edirne Enforcement Court and repeated his request for the restriction to be lifted. The court dismissed that application on 11 April 2013, holding that there had not been any change in the circumstances of the applicant and the decision relating to the restriction on the consultations with the applicant’s lawyer. In that connection, the court held that there was still a risk in view of the previous decisions taken in respect of the applicant by the enforcement courts as well as the lawyer’s conduct. An appeal by the applicant against that decision was rejected on 10 June 2013.
19.  At time of the adoption of this judgment, the restriction on the applicant’s right to confıdential communications with his lawyer remains in place.
B.  The applicant’s previous application with the Court and further developments
20.  On 17 February 2006 the applicant lodged an application with the Court, complaining about the Edirne Enforcement Court’s decision of 25 August 2005.
21.  On 8 December 2015 the Court delivered an inadmissibility decision on account of non-exhaustion of domestic remedies and held that the applicant had to make use of the new domestic remedy established by Law no. 6384 (see Altay and Others v. Turkey (dec.), no. 9100/06 and 155 others).
22.  On 1 November 2016 the Compensation Commission held that the Edirne Enforcement Court’s decision not to hand over the book and the periodicals sent to the applicant by his lawyer had infringed the applicant’s right to receive information within the meaning of Article 10 of the Convention. They held in that connection that the impugned decision had constituted an interference which had not been based on relevant and sufficient reasons, notably because the domestic court had not explained in its decision in what respect the books and magazines in question had jeopardised the security of the institution.

events.source_text: The case originated in an application (no. 11236/09) against the Republic of Turkey lodged with the Court under Article 34 of the Convention for the Protection of Human Rights and Fundamental Freedoms (“the Convention”) by a Turkish national, Mr Mehmet Aytunç Altay (“the applicant”), on 17 February 2006.
The applicant was represented by Ms G. Tuncer, a lawyer practising in Istanbul. The Turkish Government (“the Government”) were represented by their Agent.

The applicant alleged, in particular, that the restriction of the privacy of his consultations with his lawyer was incompatible with his rights under Article 8 of the Convention and that the domestic proceedings with respect to this measure had not complied with the requirements of Article 6 § 1 of the Convention.
On 17 October 2017 notice of the above complaints was given to the Government and the remainder of the application was declared inadmissible pursuant to Rule 54 § 3 of the Rules of Court.
At the time of the events relating to the application, he was serving his sentence in the Edirne F-type prison.
Since his imprisonment the applicant has been represented by his lawyer in respect of several applications, including the present application, before the Court.

On an unspecified date, the applicant’s lawyer sent a package by post to the applicant. The prison administration believed the contents of the package to be suspect and therefore lodged a request on 12 August 2005 with the public prosecutor for a decision to be taken by an enforcement court to determine whether the material sent to the applicant concerned defence-related documents or whether they concerned any objectionable content so as to prevent them from being handed over to the applicant.
events.event_who: applicant’s lawyer, prison administration, public prosecutor

events.source_text: On 25 August 2005 the Edirne Enforcement Court allowed an application by the prosecutor and examined the contents of the package, which contained a book entitled Globalisation and Imperialism ( Küreselleşme ve Emperyalizm), a magazine with the title Rootless Anational Publication ( Köxüz Anasyonal Neşriyat), and a newspaper with the title Express International Sha la la ( Express Enternasyonal Şalala). The court held that the material in question did not relate to the rights of the defence and that therefore they should not be handed over to the applicant pursuant to section 5 of Law no. 5351.
events.event_what: allowed an application, examined the contents, held that the material did not relate to the rights of the defence

events.source_text: On 16 September 2005 the applicant objected to the decision of the Edirne Enforcement Court before the Edirne Assize Court. He submitted that he had asked his lawyer to bring those books and magazines in question simply because he had wanted to read them. He submitted that it had been the prison administration which had told his lawyer that they could not be brought in person and had therefore to be sent by post. He further argued that while it was correct that they had not been related to his rights of defence, they were not illegal publications and there had been no basis for the prison administration to withhold them from him simply because they had been sent by post by his lawyer.

On 30 September 2005, the Edirne Assize Court dismissed the applicant’s objections on the basis of the case file, holding that the decision of the Edirne Enforcement Court had been in accordance with law and procedure.

In the meantime, that is to say on 16 September 2005, the prison administration lodged another request with the public prosecutor in relation to the package sent by the applicant’s lawyer. In that request, it submitted that the applicant’s lawyer’s conduct had been incompatible with her duties as a lawyer and requested that section 5 of Law no. 5351, which provides for an official to be present during consultations between a prisoner and his or her lawyer, be applied to the applicant.

On 23 September 2005, referring to its earlier decision of 25 August 2005, the Edirne Enforcement Court in an examination carried out on the basis of the case file, without holding a hearing and without seeking submissions from the applicant or his lawyer, granted an application on the part of the prison administration and therefore held that an official was to be present during the applicant’s consultations with his lawyer.
events.event_what: granted an application, held that an official was to be present

events.source_text: The decision did not specify how long the restriction was to remain in force. The Edirne Enforcement Court further held that, if requested, a separate decision would be taken as to whether the exchange of documents between the applicant and his lawyer would also be subject to a restriction.
events.event_what: held that the restriction was to remain in force, held that a separate decision would be taken

events.source_text: On 24 October 2005 the applicant objected to the decision of 23 September 2005 before the Edirne Assize Court. He submitted that the impugned decision did not explain why it was necessary to restrict the privacy of his consultations with his lawyer. He argued in that connection that a provision which provided for such a restriction could only be applied if it had emerged from documents and other evidence that visits by lawyers to a person convicted of organised crime had been serving as a means of communication within the criminal organisation in question. He argued that no such element had been present in his situation and the court had not conducted any examination in that connection. Lastly, he maintained that there were no legal provisions prohibiting the exchange of legal books and magazines between a prisoner and his lawyer.

On 27 October 2005 the Edirne Assize Court dismissed the case on the basis of the case file and without holding a hearing. Without responding to the applicant’s arguments, it held that the Edirne Enforcement Court’s decision of 23 September 2005 had been in accordance with the law and procedure.
On 29 May 2008 the applicant lodged an application with the Edirne Enforcement Court for the restriction on the conversations between him and his lawyer to be lifted.

On 4 June 2008 the applicant’s application was dismissed on the basis of the case file. The court held that the decision of 23 September 2005 had become final and that there was no need for a further examination.

The applicant lodged another application on 2 November 2010 and applied for a hearing in accordance with the new amendments to the procedure before the enforcement courts (see paragraph 27 below). On 6 December 2010 the Edirne Enforcement Court dismissed the applicant’s application for a hearing, holding that the new amendments to the procedure concerned only the examination of objections against disciplinary sanctions, so that in so far as the restriction of 23 September 2005 had not been a disciplinary sanction, no hearing could be held in respect of that complaint. It further dismissed the applicant’s application for the restriction to be lifted, holding that the decision of 23 September 2005 had been final. An appeal by the applicant against that decision was dismissed on 24 August 2011.
events.event_what: dismissed the application for a hearing, dismissed the application for the restriction to be lifted, dismissed the appeal

events.source_text: On 21 February 2013 the applicant lodged an application again with the Edirne Enforcement Court and repeated his request for the restriction to be lifted. The court dismissed that application on 11 April 2013, holding that there had not been any change in the circumstances of the applicant and the decision relating to the restriction on the consultations with the applicant’s lawyer. In that connection, the court held that there was still a risk in view of the previous decisions taken in respect of the applicant by the enforcement courts as well as the lawyer’s conduct. An appeal by the applicant against that decision was rejected on 10 June 2013.
events.event_what: dismissed the application, held that there had not been any change in the circumstances, held that there was still a risk

events.source_text: At time of the adoption of this judgment, the restriction on the applicant’s right to confidential communications with his lawyer remains in place.
On 17 February 2006 the applicant lodged an application with the Court, complaining about the Edirne Enforcement Court’s decision of 25 August 2005.

On 8 December 2015 the Court delivered an inadmissibility decision on account of non-exhaustion of domestic remedies and held that the applicant had to make use of the new domestic remedy established by Law no. 6384 (see Altay and Others v. Turkey (dec.), no. 9100/06 and 155 others).

On 1 November 2016 the Compensation Commission held that the Edirne Enforcement Court’s decision not to hand over the book and the periodicals sent to the applicant by his lawyer had infringed the applicant’s right to receive information within the meaning of Article 10 of the Convention. They held in that connection that the impugned decision had constituted an interference which had not been based on relevant and sufficient reasons, notably because the domestic court had not explained in its decision in what respect the books and magazines in question had jeopardised the security of the institution. FOR THESE REASONS, THE COURT, UNANIMOUSLY,
events.event_what: held that the decision had infringed the applicant’s right to receive information, held that the decision had not been based on relevant and sufficient reasons

events.source_text: Done in English, and notified in writing on 9 April 2019, pursuant to Rule 77 §§ 2 and 3 of the Rules of Court.

The case originated in an application (no. 11236/09) against the Republic of Turkey lodged with the Court under Article 34 of the Convention for the Protection of Human Rights and Fundamental Freedoms (“the Convention”) by a Turkish national, Mr Mehmet Aytunç Altay (“the applicant”), on 17 February 2006.
On 17 October 2017 notice of the above complaints was given to the Government and the remainder of the application was declared inadmissible pursuant to Rule 54 § 3 of the Rules of Court.

On 16 September 2005 the applicant objected to the decision of the Edirne Enforcement Court

On 24 October 2005 the applicant objected to the decision of 23 September 2005 before the Edirne Assize Court.
On 27 October 2005 the Edirne Assize Court dismissed the case
On 29 May 2008 the applicant lodged an application with the Edirne Enforcement Court for the restriction on the conversations between him and his lawyer to be lifted.
On 4 June 2008 the applicant’s application was dismissed
On 2 November 2010 and applied for a hearing
On 6 December 2010 the Edirne Enforcement Court dismissed the applicant’s application for a hearing
An appeal against that decision by the applicant was dismissed on 24 August 2011.
On 21 February 2013 the applicant lodged an application again with the Edirne Enforcement Court
The court dismissed that application on 11 April 2013
An appeal by the applicant against that decision was rejected on 10 June 2013.

On 8 December 2015 the Court delivered an inadmissibility decision

events.source_text: FOR THESE REASONS, THE COURT, UNANIMOUSLY, 1. Declares the application admissible;
2. Holds that there has been a violation of Article 8 of the Convention;
events.event_what: held that there had been a violation of Article 8 of the Convention

events.source_text: 3. Holds that there has been a violation of Article 6 § 1 of the Convention on account of lack of a hearing in the proceedings concerning the applicant;
events.event_what: held that there had been a violation of Article 6 § 1 of the Convention

events.source_text: 5. Holds (a) that the respondent State is to pay the applicant, within three months from the date on which the judgment becomes final in accordance with Article 44 § 2 of the Convention, EUR 2,000
events.event_what: ordered the respondent State to pay the applicant EUR 2,000

events.event_what: the Court delivered an inadmissibility decision, holding that applicant must use new domestic remedy Law no. 6384.

events.source_text: On 27 October 2005 the Edirne Assize Court dismissed the case on the basis of the case file and without holding a hearing.
events.event_who: Edirne Assize Court (acting on applicant's objections)
events.event_what: the Edirne Assize Court dismissed the case without holding a hearing.

events.source_text: On 1 November 2016 the Compensation Commission held that the Edirne Enforcement Court’s decision not to hand over the book and the periodicals sent to the applicant by his lawyer had infringed the applicant’s right to receive information within the meaning of Article 10 of the Convention.

On 23 September 2005, referring to its earlier decision of 25 August 2005, the Edirne Enforcement Court in an examination carried out on the basis of the case file, without holding a hearing and without seeking submissions from the applicant or his lawyer, granted an application on the part of the prison administration and therefore held that an official was to be present during the applicant’s consultations with his lawyer.
events.event_who: Edirne Enforcement Court (on behalf of prison administration)
events.event_what: the Edirne Enforcement Court granted an application for official presence during consultations.

events.source_text: On 17 October 2017 notice of the above complaints was given to the Government and the remainder of the application was declared inadmissible pursuant to Rule 54 § 3 of the Rules of Court.
On 21 February 2013 the applicant lodged an application again with the Edirne Enforcement Court and repeated his request for the restriction to be lifted.
events.event_what: lodged an application with Edirne Enforcement Court to lift restriction.

events.source_text: On 4 June 2008 the applicant’s application was dismissed on the basis of the case file. The court held that the decision of 23 September 2005 had become final and there was no need for a further examination.
On 17 February 2006 the applicant lodged an application with the Court, complaining about the Edirne Enforcement Court’s decision of 25 August 2005.

On 8 December 2015 the Court delivered an inadmissibility decision on account of non-exhaustion of domestic remedies and held that the applicant had to make use of the new domestic remedy established by Law no. 6384.
On 27 October 2005 the Edirne Assize Court dismissed the case on the basis of the case file and without holding a hearing.

On 1 November 2016 the Compensation Commission held that the Edirne Enforcement Court’s decision not to hand over the book and the periodicals sent to the applicant by his lawyer had infringed the applicant’s right to receive information within the meaning of Article 10 of the Convention.

On 29 May 2008 the applicant lodged an application with the Edirne Enforcement Court for the restriction on the conversations between him and his lawyer to be lifted.

The case originated in an application (no. 11236/09) against the Republic of Turkey lodged with the Court under Article 34 of the Convention for the Protection of Human Rights and Fundamental Freedoms ("the Convention") by a Turkish national, Mr Mehmet Aytunç Altay ("the applicant"), on 17 February 2006.
The applicant was represented by Ms G. Tuncer, a lawyer practising in Istanbul.
The Turkish Government ("the Government") were represented by their Agent.

The applicant alleged, in particular, that the restriction of the privacy of his consultations with his lawyer was incompatible with his rights under Article 8 of the Convention and that the domestic proceedings with respect to this measure had not complied with the requirements of Article 6 § 1 of the Convention.
On 17 October 2017 notice of the above complaints was given to the Government and the remainder of the application was declared inadmissible pursuant to Rule 54 § 3 of the Rules of Court.
On an unspecified date, the applicant’s lawyer sent a package by post to the applicant.
events.event: The applicant's lawyer sent a package

events.source_text: On 25 August 2005 the Edirne Enforcement Court allowed an application by the prosecutor and examined the contents of the package, which contained a book entitled Globalisation and Imperialism ( Küreselleşme ve Emperyalizm) , a magazine with the title Rootless Anational Publication ( Köxüz Anasyonal Neşriyat ) and a newspaper with the title Express International Sha la la ( Express Enternasyonal Şalala ).
events.event: The contents of the package were examined

events.source_text: The court held that the material in question did not relate to the rights of the defence and that therefore they should not be handed over to the applicant pursuant to section 5 of Law no. 5351.
events.event: The material was not handed over
events.event_what: held that the material should not be handed over

events.source_text: On 16 September 2005 the applicant objected to the decision of the Edirne Enforcement Court before the Edirne Assize Court.

On 30 September 2005, the Edirne Assize Court dismissed the applicant’s objections on the basis of the case file, holding that the decision of the Edirne Enforcement Court had been in accordance with law and procedure.
In the meantime, that is to say on 16 September 2005, the prison administration lodged another request with the public prosecutor in relation to the package sent by the applicant’s lawyer.
events.event: The prison administration lodged another request

events.source_text: On 23 September 2005, referring to its earlier decision of 25 August 2005, the Edirne Enforcement Court in an examination carried out on the basis of the case file, without holding a hearing and without seeking submissions from the applicant or his lawyer, granted an application on the part of the prison administration and therefore held that an official was to be present during the applicant’s consultations with his lawyer.
events.event: An official was ordered to be present during consultations
events.event_what: granted an application and held that an official was to be present

events.source_text: On 24 October 2005 the applicant objected to the decision of 23 September 2005 before the Edirne Assize Court.
On 27 October 2005 the Edirne Assize Court dismissed the case on the basis of the case file and without holding a hearing.
On 29 May 2008 the applicant lodged an application with the Edirne Enforcement Court for the restriction on the conversations between him and his lawyer to be lifted.
events.event: The applicant requested the lifting of the restriction

events.source_text: On 4 June 2008 the applicant’s application was dismissed on the basis of the case file.
The applicant lodged another application on 2 November 2010 and applied for a hearing in accordance with the new amendments to the procedure before the enforcement courts (see paragraph 27 below).
events.event_what: lodged another application and requested a hearing

events.source_text: On 6 December 2010 the Edirne Enforcement Court dismissed the applicant’s application for a hearing, holding that the new amendments to the procedure concerned only the examination of objections against disciplinary sanctions, so that in so far as the restriction of 23 September 2005 had not been a disciplinary sanction, no hearing could be held in respect of that complaint.
events.event: The applicant's request for a hearing was denied
events.event_what: dismissed the application for a hearing

events.source_text: On 21 February 2013 the applicant lodged an application again with the Edirne Enforcement Court and repeated his request for the restriction to be lifted.
events.event: The applicant requested the lifting of the restriction
events.event_what: lodged an application and repeated his request for the restriction to be lifted

events.source_text: At time of the adoption of this judgment, the restriction on the applicant’s right to confıdential communications with his lawyer remains in place.
events.event: The restriction on the applicant's confidential communications remains

events.source_text: On 17 February 2006 the applicant lodged an application with the Court, complaining about the Edirne Enforcement Court’s decision of 25 August 2005.
events.event: The applicant lodged an application with the European Court of Human Rights

events.source_text: On 8 December 2015 the Court delivered an inadmissibility decision on account of non-exhaustion of domestic remedies and held that the applicant had to make use of the new domestic remedy established by Law no. 6384 (see Altay and Others v. Turkey (dec.), no. 9100/06 and 155 others).
events.event: The application was declared inadmissible due to non-exhaustion of domestic remedies
events.event_who: The European Court of Human Rights

events.source_text: On 1 November 2016 the Compensation Commission held that the Edirne Enforcement Court’s decision not to hand over the book and the periodicals sent to the applicant by his lawyer had infringed the applicant’s right to receive information within the meaning of Article 10 of the Convention.
events.event: The Compensation Commission found that the Edirne Enforcement Court's decision infringed the applicant's right to receive information
events.event_what: held that the decision infringed the applicant's right to receive information

events.source_text: FOR THESE REASONS, THE COURT, UNANIMOUSLY,
events.event: The Court made a unanimous decision
events.event_who: The European Court of Human Rights

events.source_text: 1.   Declares the application admissible;
events.event_who: The European Court of Human Rights

events.source_text: 2.   Holds that there has been a violation of Article 8 of the Convention;
events.event: The Court found a violation of Article 8 of the Convention
events.event_who: The European Court of Human Rights
events.event_what: holds that there has been a violation of Article 8 of the Convention

events.source_text: 3.   Holds that there has been a violation of Article 6 § 1 of the Convention on account of lack of a hearing in the proceedings concerning the applicant;
events.event: The Court found a violation of Article 6 § 1 of the Convention due to lack of a hearing
events.event_who: The European Court of Human Rights
events.event_what: holds that there has been a violation of Article 6 § 1 of the Convention on account of lack of a hearing

events.source_text: 4.   Holds that there is no need to examine the remaining complaints under Article 6 § 1 of the Convention;
events.event: The Court decided not to examine the remaining complaints under Article 6 § 1 of the Convention
events.event_who: The European Court of Human Rights
events.event_what: holds that there is no need to examine the remaining complaints

events.source_text: 5.   Holds (a)  that the respondent State is to pay the applicant, within three months from the date on which the judgment becomes final in accordance with Article 44 § 2 of the Convention, EUR 2,000 (two thousand euros) plus any tax that may be chargeable, in respect of nonpecuniary damage, to be converted into the currency of the respondent State at the rate applicable at the date of settlement;
events.event: The Court ordered compensation for non-pecuniary damage
events.event_who: The European Court of Human Rights
events.event_what: holds that the respondent State is to pay compensation

events.source_text: 5.   Holds (b)  that from the expiry of the above-mentioned three months until settlement simple interest shall be payable on the above amount at a rate equal to the marginal lending rate of the European Central Bank during the default period plus three percentage points;
events.event: The Court ordered simple interest on the compensation amount
events.event_who: The European Court of Human Rights
events.event_what: holds that simple interest shall be payable

events.source_text: 6.   Dismisses the remainder of the applicant’s claim for just satisfaction.
events.event: The Court dismissed the remaining claim for just satisfaction
events.event_who: The European Court of Human Rights
events.event_what: dismissed the remainder of the claim

events.source_text: The case originated in an application (no. 11236/09) against the Republic of Turkey lodged with the Court under Article 34 of the Convention for the Protection of Human Rights and Fundamental Freedoms (“the Convention”) by a Turkish national, Mr Mehmet Aytunç Altay (“the applicant”), on 17 February 2006.
On 17 October 2017 notice of the above complaints was given to the Government and the remainder of the application was declared inadmissible pursuant to Rule 54 § 3 of the Rules of Court.
On an unspecified date, the applicant’s lawyer sent a package by post to the applicant.

The prison administration believed the contents of the package to be suspect and therefore lodged a request on 12 August 2005 with the public prosecutor for a decision to be taken by an enforcement court to determine whether the material sent to the applicant concerned defence-related documents or whether they concerned any objectionable content so as to prevent them from being handed over to the applicant.

On 25 August 2005 the Edirne Enforcement Court allowed an application by the prosecutor and examined the contents of the package, which contained a book entitled Globalisation and Imperialism ( Küreselleşme ve Emperyalizm) , a magazine with the title Rootless Anational Publication ( Köxüz Anasyonal Neşriyat ), and a newspaper with the title Express International Sha la la ( Express Enternasyonal Şalala ).
events.event_what: examined the contents of the package

events.source_text: On 16 September 2005 the applicant objected to the decision of the Edirne Enforcement Court before the Edirne Assize Court.

On 30 September 2005, the Edirne Assize Court dismissed the applicant’s objections on the basis of the case file, holding that the decision of the Edirne Enforcement Court had been in accordance with law and procedure.
On an unspecified date, the applicant’s lawyer sent a package by post to the applicant.
On 12 August 2005, the prison administration lodged another request with the public prosecutor in relation to the package sent by the applicant’s lawyer.

On 23 September 2005, referring to its earlier decision of 25 August 2005, the Edirne Enforcement Court in an examination carried out on the basis of the case file, without holding a hearing and without seeking submissions from the applicant or his lawyer, granted an application on the part of the prison administration and therefore held that an official was to be present during the applicant’s consultations with his lawyer.
On 24 October 2005 the applicant objected to the decision of 23 September 2005 before the Edirne Assize Court.
On 27 October 2005 the Edirne Assize Court dismissed the case on the basis of the case file and without holding a hearing.
On 29 May 2008 the applicant lodged an application with the Edirne Enforcement Court for the restriction on the conversations between him and his lawyer to be lifted.
On 4 June 2008 the applicant’s application was dismissed on the basis of the case file.
On 2 November 2010 the applicant lodged another application and applied for a hearing.
On 6 December 2010 the Edirne Enforcement Court dismissed the applicant’s application for a hearing.
On 21 February 2013 the applicant lodged an application again with the Edirne Enforcement Court and repeated his request for the restriction to be lifted.
On 11 April 2013 the Edirne Enforcement Court dismissed that application.
On 8 December 2015 the Court delivered an inadmissibility decision on account of non-exhaustion of domestic remedies.

On 1 November 2016 the Compensation Commission held that the Edirne Enforcement Court’s decision not to hand over the book and the periodicals sent to the applicant by his lawyer had infringed the applicant’s right to receive information within the meaning of Article 10 of the Convention.
events.event_what: held that a decision was unlawful

events.source_text: On 9 April 2019, the Court delivered its judgment.

The case originated in an application (no. 11236/09) against the Republic of Turkey lodged with the Court under Article 34 of the Convention for the Protection of Human Rights and Fundamental Freedoms (“the Convention”) by a Turkish national, Mr Mehmet Aytunç Altay (“the applicant”), on 17 February 2006.

The applicant alleged, in particular, that the restriction of the privacy of his consultations with his lawyer was incompatible with his rights under Article 8 of the Convention and that the domestic proceedings with respect to this measure had not complied with the requirements of Article 6 § 1 of the Convention.
events.event_when: Not specified (impliedly around the time of lodging the application)

events.source_text: On 17 October 2017 notice of the above complaints was given to the Government and the remainder of the application was declared inadmissible pursuant to Rule 54 § 3 of the Rules of Court.
On 29 May 2008 the applicant lodged an application with the Edirne Enforcement Court for the restriction on the conversations between him and his lawyer to be lifted.

On 4 June 2008 the applicant’s application was dismissed on the basis of the case file. The court held that the decision of 23 September 2005 had become final and that there was no need for a further examination.
On 17 February 2006 the applicant lodged an application with the Court, complaining about the Edirne Enforcement Court’s decision of 25 August 2005.

FOR THESE REASONS, THE COURT, UNANIMOUSLY, declares the application admissible; holds that there has been a violation of Article 8 of the Convention; holds that there has been a violation of Article 6 § 1 of the Convention on account of lack of a hearing in the proceedings concerning the applicant;

events.source_text: On 29 May 2008 the applicant lodged an application with the Edirne Enforcement Court for the restriction on the conversations between him and his lawyer to be lifted.
events.event_what: for the restriction on the conversations between him and his lawyer to be lifted.

events.source_text: On 4 June 2008 the applicant’s application was dismissed on the basis of the case file.
events.event_what: on the basis of the case file.

events.source_text: On 2 November 2010 the applicant applied for a hearing in accordance with the new amendments to the procedure before the enforcement courts.
events.event: The applicant applied for a hearing
events.event_what: in accordance with the new amendments to the procedure before the enforcement courts.

events.source_text: On 6 December 2010 the Edirne Enforcement Court dismissed the applicant’s application for a hearing
events.event: The Edirne Enforcement Court dismissed the applicant’s application

events.source_text: On 21 February 2013 the applicant lodged an application again with the Edirne Enforcement Court and repeated his request for the restriction to be lifted.
events.event_what: and repeated his request for the restriction to be lifted.

events.source_text: On 11 April 2013 the court dismissed that application on 11 April 2013, holding that there had not been any change in the circumstances of the applicant and the decision relating to the restriction on the consultations with the applicant’s lawyer.
events.event_what: holding that there had not been any change in the circumstances of the applicant and the decision relating to the restriction on the consultations with the applicant’s lawyer.

events.source_text: 1. The case originated in an application (no. 11236/09) against the Republic of Turkey lodged with the Court under Article 34 of the Convention for the Protection of Human Rights and Fundamental Freedoms ("the Convention") by a Turkish national, Mr Mehmet Aytunç Altay ("the applicant"), on 17 February 2006.
2. The applicant was represented by Ms G. Tuncer, a lawyer practising in Istanbul. The Turkish Government ("the Government") were represented by their Agent.

3. The applicant alleged, in particular, that the restriction of the privacy of his consultations with his lawyer was incompatible with his rights under Article 8 of the Convention and that the domestic proceedings with respect to this measure had not complied with the requirements of Article 6 Âµ1 of the Convention.
events.event_what: restriction of privacy, non-compliance with Article 6 Âµ1 requirements

events.source_text: 4. On 17 October 2017 notice of the above complaints was given to the Government and the remainder of the application was declared inadmissible pursuant to Rule 54 Âµ3 of the Rules of Court.

5. The applicant was born in 1956 and was convicted of attempting to undermine the constitutional order and sentenced to life imprisonment without the possibility of parole. At the time of the events relating to the application, he was serving his sentence in the Edirne F-type prison.
6. Since his imprisonment the applicant has been represented by his lawyer in respect of several applications, including the present application, before the Court.

7. On an unspecified date, the applicant's lawyer sent a package by post to the applicant. The prison administration believed the contents of the package to be suspect and therefore lodged a request on 12 August 2005 with the public prosecutor for a decision to be taken by an enforcement court to determine whether the material sent to the applicant concerned defence-related documents or whether they concerned any objectionable content so as to prevent them from being handed over to the applicant.

8. On 25 August 2005 the Edirne Enforcement Court allowed an application by the prosecutor and examined the contents of the package, which contained a book entitled Globalisation and Imperialism (Köreselleşlėe ve Emperyalizm), a magazine with the title Rootless Anational Publication (Köxüz ünasyonal Neşriyat), and a newspaper with the title Express International Şalala. The court held that the material in question did not relate to the rights of the defence and that therefore they should not be handed over to the applicant pursuant to section 5 of Law no. 5351.
9. On 16 September 2005 the applicant objected to the decision of the Edirne Enforcement Court before the Edirne Assize Court.

10. On 30 September 2005, the Edirne Assize Court dismissed the applicant's objections on the basis of the case file, holding that the decision of the Edirne Enforcement Court had been in accordance with law and procedure.
11. In the meantime, that is to say on 16 September 2005, the prison administration lodged another request with the public prosecutor in relation to the package sent by the applicant's lawyer.

12. On 23 September 2005, referring to its earlier decision of 25 August 2005, the Edirne Enforcement Court in an examination carried out on the basis of the case file, without holding a hearing and without seeking submissions from the applicant or his lawyer, granted an application on the part of the prison administration and therefore held that an official was to be present during the applicant's consultations with his lawyer.
13. On 24 October 2005 the applicant objected to the decision of 23 September 2005 before the Edirne Assize Court.
14. On 27 October 2005 the Edirne Assize Court dismissed the case on the basis of the case file and without holding a hearing.
15. On 29 May 2008 the applicant lodged an application with the Edirne Enforcement Court for the restriction on the conversations between him and his lawyer to be lifted.
16. On 4 June 2008 the applicant's application was dismissed on the basis of the case file.

17. The applicant lodged another application on 2 November 2010 and applied for a hearing in accordance with the new amendments to the procedure before the enforcement courts (see paragraph 27 below). On 6 December 2010 the Edirne Enforcement Court dismissed the applicant's application for a hearing, holding that the new amendments to the procedure concerned only the examination of objections against disciplinary sanctions, so that in so far as the restriction of 23 September 2005 had not been a disciplinary sanction, no hearing could be held in respect of that complaint. It further dismissed the applicant's application for the restriction to be lifted, holding that the decision of 23 September 2005 had been final.
18. On 21 February 2013 the applicant lodged an application again with the Edirne Enforcement Court and repeated his request for the restriction to be lifted.
19. At the time of the adoption of this judgment, the restriction on the applicant's right to confidential communications with his lawyer remains in place.
20. On 17 February 2006 the applicant lodged an application with the Court, complaining about the Edirne Enforcement Court's decision of 25 August 2005.

21. On 8 December 2015 the Court delivered an inadmissibility decision on account of non-exhaustion of domestic remedies and held that the applicant had to make use of the new domestic remedy established by Law no. 6384 (see Altay and Others v. Turkey (dec.), no. 9100/06 and 155 others).

22. On 1 November 2016 the Compensation Commission held that the Edirne Enforcement Court's decision not to hand over the book and the periodicals sent to the applicant by his lawyer had infringed the applicant's right to receive information within the meaning of Article 10 of the Convention.
